channel.title: Sudokus - Sudoku puzzle generator and solver in C
channel.description:
Examples of input can be found in the 'io' folder. Feel free to give feedback if you wish.
This is a sudoku solver and generator written in C. Notes: - sudokus executable uses formatted output. - sudokusr executable does not use formatted output. - The input provided to the solver MUST be correctly formatted! If you don't know the format, use 'sudokusr -g' for a reference. Tips: - Pipe input to the solver by using '<' (ex: sudokus -s < solveme.txt). - Pipe output to a document for portability using '>' (ex: sudokus -g > generated.txt).
[b]github:[/b] https://github.com/t4/sudokus

item.title: Sudokus - Sudoku puzzle generator and solver in C
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:9, topic:448856”][quote author=iKilem link=topic=551750.msg4042588#msg4042588 date=1341784506]
I see a potential for error since you don’t check user input or at least initialise puzzle with default values in solver().

You shouldn’t have any function or variable definitions in header files. A benefit I can think of is compile-time encapsulation. And personally, I would just call strcmp() directly instead of writing a streq() function. It doesn’t help much.
[/quote]
yes, error checking wasn’t done - i just assumed valid input.

okay, i’ll start declaring and defining in different files (header.h, impl.c etc). compile-time encapsulation? explain this please. The helper function(s) was just to conceptually help me get used std.[/quote]
Basically, if you change the implementation, you only need to re-compile that particular source file.

Read full topic
item.source: Sudokus - Sudoku puzzle generator and solver in C

[quote=“iKilem, post:8, topic:448856”]I see a potential for error since you don’t check user input or at least initialise puzzle with default values in solver().

You shouldn’t have any function or variable definitions in header files. A benefit I can think of is compile-time encapsulation. And personally, I would just call strcmp() directly instead of writing a streq() function. It doesn’t help much.[/quote]
yes, error checking wasn’t done - i just assumed valid input.

okay, i’ll start declaring and defining in different files (header.h, impl.c etc). compile-time encapsulation? explain this please. The helper function(s) was just to conceptually help me get used std.

item.title: Sudokus - Sudoku puzzle generator and solver in C
item.dc:creator: @iKilem iKilem
item.description:
@iKilem wrote:

I see a potential for error since you don’t check user input or at least initialise puzzle with default values in solver().

You shouldn’t have any function or variable definitions in header files. A benefit I can think of is compile-time encapsulation. And personally, I would just call strcmp() directly instead of writing a streq() function. It doesn’t help much.

Read full topic

@T41 wrote:

Davidi2:

Well in that case you’re probably better off at MITB General Programming… that’s where most of the C guru’s are (if they are here, they probably are at MITB too anyways)

mitb is an inactive forum and i simply link people that know C in #mopar to threads like these.

item.title: Sudokus - Sudoku puzzle generator and solver in C
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Davidi2:

Well then solving is nothing really, I made one with a GUI about a year ago, I’ll see if I can find it…

Never said it was complication. I’ve been writing stuff in C for the past few weeks in my spare time to brush up on it and become more comfortable with it. The point of posting it/having it on github is to provide a sense of progression in my knowledge of C; it also allows people who know the language to give me pointers.

Read full topic

item.title: Sudokus - Sudoku puzzle generator and solver in C
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Davidi2:

This is pretty bad, at least in terms of generation. There is a lot more to creating solvable, non-ambiguous puzzles than just using random hints along the way.

i tacked that functionality on as an extra since i noticed it could be done with a slight modification to my solving algorithm. it’s also a very naive algorithm if you haven’t noticed.

Read full topic

@T41 wrote:

Examples of input can be found in the ‘io’ folder. Feel free to give feedback if you wish.

This is a sudoku solver and generator written in C.

Notes:
- sudokus executable uses formatted output.
- sudokusr executable does not use formatted output.
- The input provided to the solver MUST be correctly formatted! If you don’t know the format, use ‘sudokusr -g’ for a reference.

Tips:
- Pipe input to the solver by using ‘<’ (ex: sudokus -s < solveme.txt).
- Pipe output to a document for portability using ‘>’ (ex: sudokus -g > generated.txt).
